Posts.Content: rseaw22 wrote: I've just been diagnosed with invasive ductal cancer in the left breast - multiple tumors.  It doesn't seem like it is in the lymph nodes, but will have a sentinel node biopsy. (I'm 47 - stage 1)  I'm big breasted - and overwhelmed.  Not because I like big breasts - just because a matching pair seems like the way it is supposed to be.  I'm overwhelmed and don't know how to begin thinking about options.  I wish we could move half of my right boob over - give me a nice pair of B's....everyone keeps telling me what a fighter and strong woman I am - quite frankly, I realize I have to get through this - not like I have a real choice to give up.  But I am wondering - if you have BC in one breast, what are the odds you will later get it in the second breast?  (don't have a family history of BC)  Am I likely to get it somewhere else in 10 years?  Ruth Dx 7/18/2008, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 1, 1/16 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: masectomy - seems like this sucks rseaw22 Mandy1313

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2008 09:21AM rseaw22 wrote: Heidi - wow, everything I read said if you are mult-focal that MAS is the only option for surgery.  Interesting that you are offered different.  I get my second opinion at Seattle Cancer Care on Aug 5th - they do a team approach and sit down with you for a couple hours to go over the entire plan from each doc (chemo, rad, surgery).  I don't know about my nodes yet - won't until after the SNB.  The masses are all close together - near the nipple... are you scheduled for radiation?  I was told that was also standard with multifocal.  I don't know how I would feel about a 10% chance - that is a very personal decision.  Seems like this is going to be a long journey...I'm eager to get the surgery (if that's what is to happen) because I really want to be able to go with my daughter when she moves into the dorms Sept 19th.  Currently surgery is scheduled for Aug 20th...
Posts.Title: masectomy - seems like this sucks rseaw22 Mandy1313

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2008 11:14PM rseaw22 wrote: HeidiB - you're right, that is a personal and very tough decision to make.  I think doing the research and talking through options helps us be comfortable with the choices we make.  None of us know if we're exactly right, overly aggressive, or not doing enough - we just have to make choices based on what the reactions to the decisions would be.  I found out meeting with my radiologist that mine is actually multicentric - 4 of the 5 tumors are in the same duct, but one isn't so that further pushes me towards the masectomy side of life.  He also said that with a mas, the skin irritation/burning is much worse - which makes me think about having both sides removed.  I can't have reconstruction for a year after radiation - which means I would go 18mo or more with one large breast.  During radiation I'd have to wear a bra to be able to go to work - all athletic things would be more difficult - back aches - just having trouble feeling like I should keep the second.  I don't know if insurance will cover removing the healthy one - that would probably be a deciding factor....
Posts.Title: masectomy - seems like this sucks rseaw22 Mandy1313

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2008 10:10AM rseaw22 wrote: Welcome to the group - congrats on the recovery from the mast - I'm going in for mine on the 20th and it is helpful to hear the positive stories.  My understanding is that you can have the expanders and the fill during rad - just not the finish.  PS are good about not doing anything before rad is ruled out.  I was talking to a 10 yr survivor yesterday and she stressed breaking each step out into its own piece - then celebrate each time you get through it.  Chemo is next for you - that gets your focus now...good luck - I know you didn't choose this, but it sounds like you are doing a great job at tackling it.  By the way, I grew up in Watkins Glen - always good to hear from strong women out of upstate NY!
Posts.Title: masectomy - seems like this sucks rseaw22 Mandy1313

Posts.Content: rseaw22 wrote: I've just been diagnosed with invasive ductal cancer in the left breast - multiple tumors.  It doesn't seem like it is in the lymph nodes, but will have a sentinel node biopsy. (I'm 47 - stage 1)  I'm big breasted - and overwhelmed.  Not because I like big breasts - just because a matching pair seems like the way it is supposed to be.  I'm overwhelmed and don't know how to begin thinking about options.  I wish we could move half of my right boob over - give me a nice pair of B's....everyone keeps telling me what a fighter and strong woman I am - quite frankly, I realize I have to get through this - not like I have a real choice to give up.  But I am wondering - if you have BC in one breast, what are the odds you will later get it in the second breast?  (don't have a family history of BC)  Am I likely to get it somewhere else in 10 years?  Ruth Dx 7/18/2008, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 1, 1/16 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: masectomy - seems like this sucks rseaw22 Mandy1313

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2008 11:00AM rseaw22 wrote: Beth, I have to wait because of radiation.  No plastic surgeon will touch it until a year after.  (at least in Spokane).  I am not soo young - 47 - unless you ask a BC doc, then I hit the young category.
Posts.Title: masectomy - seems like this sucks rseaw22 Mandy1313

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2008 06:44PM rseaw22 wrote: So I guess this is how a saga starts.  I heard my surgeon's view today - mastectomy - chemo might be optional, though she thinks even if the lymph nodes are clear it will still be recommended because I'm young.  Radiation because research indicates that the multi-focal? masses have probably gotten into the skin - and because radiation = no reconstruction until after.  She didn't like the idea of removing the second healthy breast - but does say it is definitely my decision.  She said percentage of people doing this to a healthy breast (without any family history) is up to about 5 % and a fair amount of regret reported. (she gave the analogy of the arm - but I think that's bogus because my arms have function - I'm really just looking for matching space at this point.)  The odds of getting cancer later in the 2nd breast are minimal - and no higher than anywhere else in the body (nice, odd comfort there).  She suggested waiting until after radiation to let the plastic surgeon make everything match.  Angie - I laughed when you said yours sag.  You are not going to believe what gravity and an additonal decade will do.  I really don't want one perky and one sag - but definitely don't want to pay for 2 sagging!   Mentally I had walked into the visit prepared for discussing mastectomy with immediate recon and chemo only.  So much for my plans - it seems like I sort of get my mind wrapped around it, then somehow I feel like I was punched in the gut with an iron fist again.
Posts.Title: masectomy - seems like this sucks rseaw22 Mandy1313

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2008 04:02PM rseaw22 wrote: I just finished my 1 tx of chemo and for pain mgmt they switched me to ibuprofen.  I definitely noticed fullness, heaviness in my left arm when taking it.  Today they diagnosed me with Lymphodema - don't know that ibuprofen caused it, but it made me notice it.  Interestingly, during the same appt they told me to go ahead and keep using ibuprofen for pain mgmt during the next tx.  :)  I see a PT tomorrow who specializes in bc lymphodema tx - hopefully she'll have a some help for me....
Posts.Title: Ibuprofen and LE bomber410 PinkWarriorPrincess

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2008 12:05AM rseaw22 wrote: thanks - that sounds good.  I still have my drains so am limited in clothing choices - 3 zip ups and a huge silk shirt.  I'm hoping to make a quick trip to the mall this week to get a second silk top that will fit a little better.  :)  Wrapping the arm lightly sounds good.  I am going to try to get connected with a PT - I'll be having radiation which will increase my chances of getting lymphodema so getting a start on dealing with it sounds good.
Posts.Title: skin sensitivity - help? rseaw22 rseaw22

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2008 11:13AM rseaw22 wrote: The power of venting - I breathed deep and decided to just tell my husband.  He's pouting slightly but on his way to town to get the hose.  He told me to start waking him up in the morning - I said no, I'm not your mother - if you want to help, plan to get up.  This is tense but hopefully will equal progress...
Posts.Title: AUGUST/SEPT SURGERIES?? harmonysun museumlover

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2008 12:24AM rseaw22 wrote: I got part of the path report back - 3 out of 3 nodes have microscopic cancer.  Tomorrow the doctors will hear the full report on the other 4 masses and come up with a recommendation.  I had believed the nodes would be clear so wouldn't have to have chemo or axillary node dissection.  Now it looks like both are in my future - cancer continues to suck. I was so excited about how well I was recovering - feeling realy positive this morning on my walk - now it just seems like a much longer journey...I went for a walk after I heard the news - that helped but I'm still having a private pity party.
Posts.Title: AUGUST/SEPT SURGERIES?? harmonysun museumlover

Posts.Content: rseaw22 wrote: I had the axillary nodes dissected last week and am having major skin sensitivity on my upper arm - anybody have any solutions for this?  Sometimes it doesn't bother me, but other times I'd like to cut my arm off.  Ruth Dx 7/18/2008, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 1, 1/16 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: skin sensitivity - help? rseaw22 rseaw22

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2008 11:49PM rseaw22 wrote: I'm getting a left mast on Aug 13th - meeting with the ocon and rad before so that I will be able to better focus on what they are saying and the choices I will have.  (My surgeon's suggestion)
Posts.Title: Surery in August? ladyleen4 aurabelle

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2008 10:56AM rseaw22 wrote: So come to find out the mental part is the bigger problem for me.  I can't stand how tense everyone in the house is over little things - like if dinner prep is going well.  I can't stand reminding my dh to get things for me I asked him to get weeks before the surgery - like a shower hose nossel for the bathroom.  I can't stand how everyone is bragging about how little pain I'm in and totally ignoring the fact that I am overwhelmed by the loss of my breast.  How they are turning away offers from friends to help and then ignoring my needs.  Yesterday I fixed lunch for myself at 2 pm because I was starving.  I know that they are so used to seeing me as a strong woman that they just stay in their normal roles - I just needed to vent a bit.  So if you're reading this and a husband or friend - put a schedule together and make sure food and help is waiting.  When I have to ask for help it is much harder.  If the food goes ignored, so be it - but at least it shows the thought.  I know my family loves me - thank god none of them thought of going into nursing.  Today I got up at 8am and can't let the dogs out (gate is too heavy) so went for a walk - got back at 9 and cleaned my drains, brushed my teeth and fixed my bfast so I could take my pills...I know this all gets better - just really needed to vent.  I read somewhere that just because someone loves you doesn't make them a good listener - same is true for helper.
Posts.Title: AUGUST/SEPT SURGERIES?? harmonysun museumlover

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2008 01:44PM rseaw22 wrote: My underarm is numb too - I think for most people it's temporary.  It seemed like yesterday my nerves were all re-igniting - had weird feelings all over my chest, arm, and hand.  I definitely felt my worst yesterday - though no vomiting.  I was on pain meds almost all day.  Today is a bit better - my incision is starting to hurt some - I guess that's progress.  One of my drains was doing really well - but this morning was at 25 all by itself - sad.  This morning my daughter was up at 7:30 making me bfast so I could take my antibiotic on schedule - that was nice.  Tomorrow I should hear on the nodes - hopefully they will be clear....time for my nap...
Posts.Title: AUGUST/SEPT SURGERIES?? harmonysun museumlover

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2008 08:33AM rseaw22 wrote: It's been 1 week since I came home from the axillary node dissection - and 18 days since the mast - I'm still on oxycodone every 3 hours with ibuprofen every 6 hours - I hate taking pain meds but am having a rough time getting through the node disection.  Hopefully today will be a better day.  I keep comparing the recovery from the two - which is not fair.  I finally figured out that a lot of the problem lies with the fact my surgeon didn't tell me that the nodes would probably be more painful as they cut nerves - she said if you do well with one, then you typically do well with the other.  The surgical nurse was reviewing some pain info with me this week, and told me - I need to slow way down and just pretend I don't have a left arm for a couple of weeks and that the nerve sever causes a lot of pain issues.  sigh.  It does help reading all of your posts and knowing I'm not going through this alone.  Hope everyone's day is better than yesterday.
Posts.Title: AUGUST/SEPT SURGERIES?? harmonysun museumlover

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2008 09:58AM rseaw22 wrote: Rio - wow, I completely understand "trying to be positive for family and employees" - I finally told my husband Sunday that he needed to be aware that was an act and I really wasn't "fine" - this is a major stress I'm dealing with and he needs to be prepared for when the act falls away.  I don't think he believes me - but at least I tried to warn him.  It's a ridiculous time to be protecting everyone else - I most worry about my girls seeing me cry.  To add to the pity factor - I haven't started my period yet which doesn't mean I'm preg, but probably means I'll start in the hospital or today and have to wear pads instead of tampons - and at this point, that just seems rude. As to the SNB - I'm getting a injection from nuclear medicine at 3:30 today then surgery tomorrow.  We live close, so it isn't a big deal.  I hadn't heard of having the snb prior to the main surgery - that seems better than having to come back 3 days later to have the nodes out...  Best of luck to all -
Posts.Title: AUGUST/SEPT SURGERIES?? harmonysun museumlover

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2008 11:50AM rseaw22 wrote: I'm getting a left side mast with snb on the 20th - no recon.  I'm doing all the prep shopping today - and still trying to figure out about bras - I'm a 38DD - do I just go bra-less for a couple of weeks?  Otherwise I'm very eager to get started with the process - just trying to keep busy and not think about the process.
Posts.Title: AUGUST/SEPT SURGERIES?? harmonysun museumlover

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2008 12:28AM rseaw22 wrote: Hey all - I had my mast yesterday and home today at 11 am.  I didn't have recon and am on almost no pain meds - decent arm movement.  I lost it at the nuclear med on Tuesday - felt sorry for the nurse but everyone has to have a breaking point.  For me they told me to put on a gown that wasn't snapped together so I had to figure out how to make the sleeves - yup, that equaled a breakdown.  I find out by monday if the nodes were clear - if not, I'm back in to have them removed after labor day...needless to say, I'm hoping to avoid that.  I'm tired and feel bruised - the drains are easier than I thought, but I will be glad when they are out.  I got my hair cut short before I went in and am very glad - I squeezed a washcloth over it this morning and could just finger it straight again.  That plus brushed teeth, and I felt almost human.  The hospital food sucked - fortunately my daughter sent in some fresh peaches and yogurt with flax, a can of almonds and some crackers - heaven!  I was really bored in the hospital so was glad I had some magazines to thumb through - TV was too busy and bugged me most of the time.  Anyway, just thought I'd let you know I've made it through.
Posts.Title: AUGUST/SEPT SURGERIES?? harmonysun museumlover
